content.question: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.A group of students wishes to experimentally verify the equation for the equivalent spring constant when springs are connected in series: <math alttext="The fraction with numerator 1 and denominator k sub equilibrium comma series, end fraction, equals the sum over n of, the fraction with numerator 1, and denominator k sub n" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msub><mi>k</mi><mtext>eq, series</mtext></msub></mfrac><mo>=</mo><munder><mo>∑</mo><mi>n</mi></munder><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msub><mi>k</mi><mi>n</mi></msub></mfrac></mstyle></math>. Available to the students are a number of identical ideal springs, a set of metal cylinders of different, known masses, and other equipment normally found in a physics laboratory.(a) Describe an experimental procedure that would allow the students to verify the equation for <math alttext="k sub equilibrium comma series" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>k</mi><mtext>eq, series</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>. Make your description detailed enough that another student could replicate the experiment, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

frqParts.text: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.A group of students wishes to experimentally verify the equation for the equivalent spring constant when springs are connected in series: <math alttext="The fraction with numerator 1 and denominator k sub equilibrium comma series, end fraction, equals the sum over n of, the fraction with numerator 1, and denominator k sub n" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msub><mi>k</mi><mtext>eq, series</mtext></msub></mfrac><mo>=</mo><munder><mo>∑</mo><mi>n</mi></munder><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msub><mi>k</mi><mi>n</mi></msub></mfrac></mstyle></math>. Available to the students are a number of identical ideal springs, a set of metal cylinders of different, known masses, and other equipment normally found in a physics laboratory.(a) Describe an experimental procedure that would allow the students to verify the equation for <math alttext="k sub equilibrium comma series" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>k</mi><mtext>eq, series</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>. Make your description detailed enough that another student could replicate the experiment, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

(b) Describe how the data obtained from the procedure described in part (a) could be analyzed in order to verify the equation for <math alttext="k sub equilibrium comma series" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>k</mi><mtext>eq, series</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>.Next, the students are given a spring that is non-ideal. The spring exerts a force of magnitude <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi></math> that depends on the change in spring length, <math alttext="delta x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>x</mi></math>, according to the equation <math alttext="F equals, k sub 1, end sub, times delta x, plus k sub 3, end sub, open parenthesis, delta x, close parenthesis, cubed" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>3</mn></msup></math>, where <math alttext="k sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="k sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> are positive constants. The constant <math alttext="k sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> has already been determined to be equal to <math alttext="10.0 Newtons per meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>10.0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>N</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>m</mtext></math>, and the students wish to determine the value of <math alttext="k sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>. The students make measurements of <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi></math> and <math alttext="delta x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>x</mi></math>, producing the data shown in the table.<math alttext="F, in Newtons" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>N</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></math><math alttext="delta x, in meters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>x</mi><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>m</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></math><math alttext="2.0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.0</mn></math><math alttext="0.197" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.197</mn></math><math alttext="3.50" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3.50</mn></math><math alttext="0.341" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.341</mn></math><math alttext="4.50" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4.50</mn></math><math alttext="0.429" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.429</mn></math><math alttext="5.50" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5.50</mn></math><math alttext="0.517" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.517</mn></math>

(c)i. What quantities could be graphed to yield a straight line that could be used to calculate an experimental value for <math alttext="k sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>?Horizontal axis:__________ Vertical axis:__________Use the remaining columns in the table, as needed, to record any quantities indicated that are not already provided in the table. Label each column and include units.

ii. On the following grid, plot the data points for the quantities indicated in part (c)(i). Clearly scale and label all axes, including units. On the same grid, draw a straight line that best represents the data.
(d) Using the line drawn in part (c)(ii), calculate an experimental value for <math alttext="k sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>.

skill.text: 1.B: Create quantitative graphs with appropriate scales and units, including plotting data.
